citation.article-title: Bacillus koreensis sp. nov., a spore-forming bacterium, isolated from the rhizosphere of willow roots in Korea
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Bacillus koreensis sp. nov.
Bacillus koreensis (ko.re.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. koreensis pertaining to Korea).
Colonies are yellow–cream, smooth, convex and circular/slightly irregular.
Cells are approximately 0·8–1·6 μm wide and 1·6–2·8 μm long.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Growth occurs at 15–48 °C (optimum 35–40 °C), pH 4·5–9·0 (optimum pH 7·0) and 0–9 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum 0–3 %).
Aesculin, casein, starch and urea are hydrolysed.
Hydrolysis of Tween 80, l-tyrosine, hypoxanthine and xanthine is not observed.

Acids are produced from d-glucose, d-fructose, d-ribose, α-d-lactose, maltose, d-trehalose, d-raffinose, glycerol, sucrose and d-melibiose, but not from d-mannitol, d-xylose, l-arabinose, l-rhamnose, adonitol or d-mannose.
The cell wall contains A1γ type peptidoglycan with m-DAP as the diagnostic diamino acid.
Predominant polar lipids are PG, DPG, PE and unknown PL1 and PL2.
Predominant cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, iso-C15 : 0, iso-C14 : 0 and iso-C16 : 0.
The type strain, BR030T (=KCTC 3914T=DSM 16467T), was isolated from the rhizosphere of willow roots in Korea.
